nodes.bodyText: why implement static method, instead of just using public method like this.isRealTimeDetector()?

We need to use this static method to check if a detector is realtime or not before create detector instance. Check here: https://github.com/opendistro-for-elasticsearch/anomaly-detection/pull/329/files#diff-ab4bf6eb04e845b21b1182e30afb84c73b282bae5cc26dbcfef2e846211bcdecR475
what's different between created and init?  Is INIT for the model training state?

+
+public enum ADTaskState {
+    CREATED,
+    INIT,

nodes.bodyText:
Created: when user start a historical detector, we will create one task to track the detector execution and set its state as CREATED
Initializing: after task created, coordinate node will gather all node’s state and dispatch task to the worker node with lowest load. When the worker node receives the request, it will set the task state as INIT immediately, then start to run cold start to train RCF model.

nodes.bodyText: what's the reason that there is a null check in the first method, not in the second one?
Good catch, should change the readOptionalInstant to readInstant, and readInstant will throw exception if it's null.
minor: endTime can't be  null, right?

Yes, for initial release, we plan to separate historical detector and realtime detector flow, so it's true the endTime can't be null. Next phase we will build universal flow, then the endTime could be null. If the endTime is null, we will pre-train model with historical data from startTime to now, then start realtime detection with the pre-trained model.
